title: Matchett Herring Coe
text:
Matchett Herring Coe (1907–1999) was an American sculptor active in Texas.
Coe was born in Loeb (now <a href="Lumberton%2C%20Texas">Lumberton</a>), Texas and lived in the Beaumont area most of his life. He graduated from <a href="Lamar%20College">Lamar College</a>, attended <a href="Cranbrook%20Educational%20Community">Cranbrook Educational Community</a> and served with the <a href="Seabees">Seabees</a> on <a href="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a> during World War II, but was active as a sculptor before the war. His works have been featured at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh, and the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D. C.
Several of his best known works include his 1936 commissioned sculpture of Confederate hero <a href="Richard%20W.%20Dowling">Richard W. Dowling</a> at <a href="Sabine%20Pass%2C%20Texas">Sabine Pass, Texas</a> for the Texas Centennial. Coe also created the 1961 statue of the Texas Confederate Veteran featured at the Vicksburg National Military Park in Mississippi.
